results.title: Early handling of spinal injuries
results.creator_credit: Walford Hewitson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Shows what to do and what not to do in the way of on-the-spot first aid when industrial back injuries occur. Animation illustrates the structure of the spinal column and how paralysis may result from injury to the inner spinal cord. Detailed demonstrations, both in a factory and in a logging camp, show how an accident victim must be handled in order to avoid more serious complications.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Walford Hewitson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Handling
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
A brief quiz on how, or how not, to handle heavy loads. In a two-minute test the audience is invited to spot nine mistakes in handling methods. Men are seen working with packing cases, cement sacks, oil drums and metal rods - and having trouble. After the test, the same workers are shown doing their jobs the right way.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Machines
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
Minor carelessness in handling machinery may lead to a major accident. Investigating a fatal accident involving a power saw, the film reconstructs the steps leading up to the fatality and shows the worker’s two key mistakes in handling the saw.

results.title: Organization
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Accidents don’t happen”.
How safety committees can lower the accident rate in industry. A typical committee is shown in action, investigating danger spots and reporting on hazards such as bad lighting and uneven floors. Careful training and supervision of new workers is also seen as a responsibility of the safety committee.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Mulholland, Fred Lasse and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Who protects the worker?
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Free to choose”.
Trade unions, claims Milton Friedman, benefit members at other workers’ expense; government employees gain higher wages at the expense of the taxpayer. Higher wages and better working conditions would result from a free labor market. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: Who protects the consumer?
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman disputes the view that consumers need governmental protection against the business community and that government actions tend to make consumers better off. The best protection, he claims, is the free market where consumers will desert inferior products or sevices. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: From cradle to grave
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman examines government spending, claiming that it leads to fraud and abuse and may not help the very people it sets out to assist. Self-help projects will, he claims, generate work and lead to a more efficient and dynamic system than the Welfare State can provide. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Dragon stirs
results.creator_credit: Liu Chun, Qi Kejun, Xue Song, Chen Meng, Lin Xiezhong, Wei Bin, Yuan Zhengming, Yu Bo, Zhao Shujing, ABC-TV (Australia), CCTV and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: A four-part historical series about China with the first two parts focussing on two major natural disasters which occurred during the 20th century and the final two parts exploring the role of China’s women and their struggle for equality. Narrated by Peter George and Diana McLean.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Liu Chun, Qi Kejun, Xue Song, Chen Meng, Lin Xiezhong, Wei Bin, Yuan Zhengming, Yu Bo, Zhao Shujing, ABC-TV (Australia), CCTV and Southern Star Entertainment
